title: Stochastic Processes and Active Inference
description: Mathematical treatment of stochastic processes and their role in modeling temporal dynamics in Active Inference.
learning_objectives: Understand stochastic processes in Active Inference
Model temporal dependencies in generative models

content.overview: Stochastic processes provide the mathematical foundation for modeling temporal dynamics in Active Inference. They describe how system states evolve over time and enable prediction, filtering, and control in dynamic environments.

markov_processes.definition: Future state depends only on current state: p(s_{t+1} | s_t, s_{t-1}, ...) = p(s_{t+1} | s_t) - Markov property
markov_processes.transition_matrix: P(s_{t+1} = j | s_t = i) = p_{ij} - stochastic matrix with rows summing to 1
markov_processes.stationary_distribution: π such that π = πP - left eigenvector with eigenvalue 1, represents long-term state probabilities
markov_processes.ergodicity: Irreducible and aperiodic Markov chains converge to unique stationary distribution from any initial state
markov_processes.absorbing_states: States with p_{ii} = 1; absorbing Markov chains eventually reach absorbing states
markov_processes.periodic_states: States with greatest common divisor of return times > 1; periodic chains oscillate between classes
markov_processes.reversible_processes: Detailed balance π_i p_{ij} = π_j p_{ji}; reversible chains have symmetric transition structure
markov_processes.continuous_time_markov: Q-matrix with q_{ij} ≥ 0 for i≠j, q_{ii} = -∑_{k≠i} q_{ik}; exponential waiting times

continuous_time_processes.stochastic_differential_equations: dX_t = μ(X_t,t)dt + σ(X_t,t)dW_t - Ito or Stratonovich interpretation
continuous_time_processes.wiener_process: W_t with independent increments W_{t+s} - W_t ~ N(0,s), continuous paths but nowhere differentiable
continuous_time_processes.ito_process: X_t = X_0 + ∫ μ(X_s)ds + ∫ σ(X_s)dW_s - non-anticipating with respect to filtration
continuous_time_processes.ornstein_uhlenbeck: dX_t = θ(μ - X_t)dt + σ dW_t - stationary distribution N(μ, σ²/(2θ))
continuous_time_processes.geometric_brownian_motion: dX_t = μ X_t dt + σ X_t dW_t - multiplicative noise, X_t > 0
continuous_time_processes.cox_ingersoll_ross: dX_t = κ(θ - X_t)dt + σ √X_t dW_t - square-root process for interest rates
continuous_time_processes.jump_diffusion: dX_t = μ(X_t)dt + σ(X_t)dW_t + ∑ dJ_t - combines continuous diffusion with discrete jumps
continuous_time_processes.levy_processes: Infinite activity processes with independent, stationary increments

filtering_and_smoothing.kalman_filter: p(x_t|y_{1:t}) = N(μ_t, Σ_t) with μ_t = μ_{t|t-1} + K_t(y_t - Cμ_{t|t-1}), Σ_t = (I - K_t C)Σ_{t|t-1}
filtering_and_smoothing.extended_kalman: Linearize nonlinear dynamics f(x) ≈ f(μ) + F(μ)(x-μ) around current estimate
filtering_and_smoothing.unscented_kalman: Use sigma points to capture nonlinear statistics without linearization
filtering_and_smoothing.ensemble_kalman: Monte Carlo approximation with ensemble of state estimates
filtering_and_smoothing.particle_filter: N particles {x_t^{(i)}, w_t^{(i)}} with importance sampling and resampling
filtering_and_smoothing.smoothing: p(x_t|y_{1:T}) using forward-backward algorithm or Rauch-Tung-Striebel smoother
filtering_and_smoothing.nonlinear_smoothing: Extended Kalman smoother or particle smoother for nonlinear systems
filtering_and_smoothing.optimal_filtering: Minimum variance estimation given all available measurements

temporal_generative_models.hidden_markov_models: p(y_{1:T}, s_{1:T}) = p(s_1) ∏ p(s_t|s_{t-1}) ∏ p(y_t|s_t) - discrete latent states
temporal_generative_models.linear_dynamical_systems: x_{t+1} = A x_t + w_t, y_t = C x_t + v_t with w_t ~ N(0,Q), v_t ~ N(0,R)
temporal_generative_models.nonlinear_dynamical_systems: x_{t+1} = f(x_t) + w_t, y_t = g(x_t) + v_t - general nonlinear state space models
temporal_generative_models.switching_models: Multiple dynamical regimes with transitions between modes s_t ∈ {1,...,K}
temporal_generative_models.state_space_models: General framework: p(x_{0:T}, y_{1:T}) = p(x_0) ∏ p(x_t|x_{t-1}) ∏ p(y_t|x_t)
temporal_generative_models.gaussian_processes: x_t as GP with covariance function k(t,t'), observations y_t = x_t + noise
temporal_generative_models.recurrent_neural_networks: x_{t+1} = f(W x_t + U y_t + b) - learned temporal dependencies
temporal_generative_models.latent_variable_models: Hierarchical generative models with temporal structure at each level

examples.name: Random Walk
examples.description: Simple discrete-time stochastic process with independent steps
examples.mean_displacement: E[s_t] = (2p-1)t - expected position scales linearly with time
examples.variance: Var(s_t) = 4p(1-p)t - diffusive spread increases with time
examples.active_inference_connection: Models random exploration behavior with no temporal correlations

examples.name: Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Process
examples.description: Mean-reverting continuous process with Gaussian stationary distribution
examples.stationary_distribution: N(μ, σ²/(2θ)) - Gaussian with mean μ and variance σ²/(2θ)
examples.correlation_function: Cov(X_t, X_0) = (σ²/(2θ)) e^{-θ|t|} - exponential decay of correlations
examples.active_inference_connection: Models belief trajectories that are pulled toward prior expectations

examples.name: Poisson Process
examples.description: Counting process for rare events occurring at constant rate
examples.definition: N_t ~ Poisson(λt), independent increments N_{t+s} - N_t ~ Poisson(λs)
examples.interarrival_times: Exponential distribution with rate λ between events
examples.memorylessness: Future behavior depends only on current count, not past timing
examples.active_inference_connection: Models event timing in decision-making under uncertainty

examples.name: Geometric Brownian Motion
examples.description: Multiplicative stochastic process for positive quantities
examples.sde: dX_t = μ X_t dt + σ X_t dW_t
examples.solution: X_t = X_0 exp((μ - σ²/2)t + σ W_t) - lognormal distribution
examples.active_inference_connection: Models belief precision or resource accumulation with multiplicative uncertainty

examples.name: Hidden Markov Model for Behavior
examples.description: Discrete latent states generating observable behavior sequences
examples.model: States s_t ∈ {foraging, resting, hiding}, observations y_t ∈ {movement, stillness}
examples.learning: EM algorithm to learn transition and emission probabilities
examples.active_inference_connection: Models behavioral state inference from observed actions

examples.name: Neural Spike Trains
examples.description: Point process model for neuronal spiking activity
examples.likelihood: p(spikes|λ) = exp(-∫λ_t dt) ∏ λ_{t_i} for spike times t_i
examples.estimation: Point process filtering or GLM fitting to estimate λ_t
examples.active_inference_connection: Models prediction errors in neural population coding

connections_to_active_inference.temporal_inference: Belief updating over time sequences using filtering and smoothing algorithms
connections_to_active_inference.predictive_control: Expected free energy minimization over temporal horizons with stochastic dynamics
connections_to_active_inference.learning_dynamics: Learning transition models p(s_{t+1}|s_t,a_t) from experience using EM or RL
connections_to_active_inference.uncertainty_propagation: How epistemic uncertainty evolves through stochastic state transitions
connections_to_active_inference.partially_observable_markov_decision_pro: Active Inference as POMDP with beliefs as states
connections_to_active_inference.stochastic_optimal_control: Policies that account for noise in state transitions and observations
connections_to_active_inference.temporal_credit_assignment: How past actions influence current and future outcomes
connections_to_active_inference.exploration_exploitation: Balancing stochastic exploration with deterministic exploitation

information_theoretic_analysis.entropy_rate: h = lim_{T→∞} (1/T) H(X_{1:T}) - average entropy production per time step
information_theoretic_analysis.mutual_information_rate: I(X;Y) = lim_{T→∞} (1/T) I(X_{1:T}; Y_{1:T}) - information shared between processes
information_theoretic_analysis.predictive_information: I(X_{t+1:T}; X_{1:t}) - how much future can be predicted from past
information_theoretic_analysis.transfer_entropy: T_{X→Y} = H(Y_{t+1}|Y_{1:t}) - H(Y_{t+1}|Y_{1:t}, X_{1:t}) - directed information flow
information_theoretic_analysis.excess_entropy: E = lim_{T→∞} H(X_{1:T}) - T h - total temporal correlations
information_theoretic_analysis.granger_causality: X Granger-causes Y if past X improves prediction of future Y
information_theoretic_analysis.integrated_information: Φ = H(X) - ∑ H(X_i) + ∑ I(X_i; X_j) - integrated causal structure
information_theoretic_analysis.active_inference_information: Expected free energy as information-theoretic objective for control

interactive_exercises.description: Implement and compare different stochastic process simulations
interactive_exercises.active_inference_connection: Relate process properties to belief dynamics

interactive_exercises.description: Implement and compare filtering algorithms for state estimation
interactive_exercises.application: Apply to Active Inference belief updating

interactive_exercises.description: Learn temporal generative models from sequential data
Analyze information flow in stochastic processes and systems
interactive_exercises.active_inference_relevance: Understanding directed information flow in inference

common_misconceptions.clarification: Markov assumption simplifies modeling but many real processes have longer-range dependencies
common_misconceptions.evidence: Neural spike trains, financial time series, and human behavior often show non-Markovian structure
common_misconceptions.consequence: Markov models can be inadequate for systems with long temporal correlations

common_misconceptions.misconception: Filtering and state estimation require linear Gaussian models
common_misconceptions.clarification: Advanced nonlinear filtering methods (EKF, UKF, particle filters) handle general nonlinear systems
common_misconceptions.evidence: Particle filters can approximate posterior distributions for arbitrary nonlinear models
common_misconceptions.practical_impact: Modern filtering enables inference in complex real-world systems

common_misconceptions.misconception: Stochastic processes are inherently unpredictable and random
common_misconceptions.clarification: Stochastic processes have statistical regularities and predictability that can be exploited
common_misconceptions.evidence: Weather forecasting, financial modeling, and neural decoding all use stochastic process models
common_misconceptions.active_inference_view: Stochasticity enables exploration while statistical structure enables learning

common_misconceptions.misconception: Continuous-time processes are just limits of discrete-time processes
common_misconceptions.clarification: Continuous-time processes have fundamentally different properties (infinitesimal generators, path continuity)
common_misconceptions.evidence: Wiener process is nowhere differentiable while discrete random walks have finite variation
common_misconceptions.mathematical_distinction: Requires different mathematical tools (Ito calculus vs. discrete probability)

common_misconceptions.misconception: All stationary processes converge to their stationary distribution
common_misconceptions.clarification: Only ergodic processes guarantee convergence; non-ergodic processes may not mix properly
common_misconceptions.evidence: Periodic Markov chains never converge to a single stationary distribution
common_misconceptions.importance: Ergodicity is crucial for reliable long-term statistical inference
